body.description: The apocalypse is over, but the journey is only beginning. The world may not have ended after the Meteor fell, but life has forever changed for the survivors of the cataclysm. Mako is no longer a viable source of energy, and an incurable new disease is spreading amid the societal upheaval. But even when brought face-to-face with grief, regret, and despair, people will find a way to pave their own path to the future-to stand tall and live. This collection of short stories serves as an epilogue to one of the most beloved installments of the hit Final Fantasy video game series, as well as a prequel to the cinematic follow-up, Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children. A must-own for enthusiasts and newcomers alike! Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Highly recommended for FFVII fans!
reviews.reviewText: It's wonderful that Western fans finally have the novel that connects the original FFVII game with the Advent Children (Complete) film! It might've been a long time coming, but I'm happy to own a copy of this instead of relying on (the wonderfully done) fan translations. This translation felt completely natural (similar to the recent English Ultimania Vol 2, which I also reviewed), but unlike that Ultimania, I happily didn't notice any translation errors in this.I'm an old-school FFVII fan (from '97-98) so I'm only familiar with the western-released Compilation titles, but this novel does a great job of tying in what challenges the cast face before the madness in Advent Children begins. Since this book's a part of the Compilation project, her name's rendered as "Aerith" rather than "Aeris" (I'm honestly fine with either, since that was a translation error back in the day.)I especially loved the banter between Barret and Cid! And Tifa's feelings (as well as her relationship with Cloud) was incredibly touching to read. You get an honest sense of just how close their family grew before Geostigma seriously affected Denzel and Cloud.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beautifully written, accurately translated.
reviews.reviewText: What a great collection! The english version tries its best, and succeeds in capturing the nuances of its Japanese counterpart. All are written in third-person limited, with each "section" focusing on one character. The original Japanese author has also posted about this on their personal twitter and approved of said translations. It's a must have for all FF7 fans, a great collection of novellas set before the events of Advent Children. It also includes beautifully rendered character illustrations in the beginning. With such a cheap price, it's a fantastic deal!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A nice bridge from original game to the follow up movie and games
reviews.reviewText: Final Fantasy VII On the Way to a Smile is a supplementary novella made up of six interconnected episodes and six short interludes following members of the original FF7 game. In a pleasant prose that takes us quickly through roughly two years of time from the various character perspectives, the short works create a clear picture of a world that has suffered a catastrophe and are now threatened by its aftermath in the form of a growing pandemic and the threatening return of a dangerous adversary. A few new characters add depth to this world allowing the reader to imagine it largely without input from the game which is beneficial for anyone seeking a quick and interesting read. It ends having covered its own story well enough to set up the characters for their appearance in the film Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children Complete. There are several very nice still shots of the character renders for that film included at the beginning of the text.Kazushige Nojima has written much of FF VII and its related material, and I have searched for other books he may have written purely because of what I have read here and in the FF VII Remake tie-in book Traces of Two Pasts. This text and the film that follows it are attached to the original game, serving less as an epilogue and more as a well crafted bridge.Four out of five stars, and very much recommended.

reviews.reviewText: I pre-ordered this book after seeing their booth at New York Comic Con. The stories are unique to each character and keeps you wanting more. I would only recommend this to those that have completed the game and have seen Advent Children.

Me agrado ver la perspectiva de muchos de los personajes después de que terminara el juego original, la única historia que no me agrado mucho fue la de Nanaki, pero fuera de eso todas las demás historias me parecieron geniales
bon roman qui dirige l'histoire romantique

Primeiro, fiz o pedido e chegou muito rápido! Comprei no domingo e terça já estava comigo.Segundo, mesmo não sendo fluente em inglês comprei a novel. Amo final Fantasy vii e acho que todo fã deveria ter... O livro traz muita informação interessante, que expande o conhecimento que temos nos jogos.~ Tem uma parte da novel que o Final Fantasy VII Remake faz uma referência:“Enquanto Cloud se lembrar de mim, posso continuar existindo. Dentro do Lifestream e na superfície. Mesmo que meu espírito se espalhe, mesmo que apenas um fragmento de uma memória corra pelo planeta, no final posso contar com a consciência de Cloud para me trazer de volta. "- Lifestream Back.No jogo o Sephiroth diz para Cloud:Se o planeta morresse, muitas coisas se perderiam. (...) Aquilo que nos une não seria mais. E eu não gostaria de viver em um mundo assim. É por isso que devo lhe pedir este único favor. (...) Corra, Cloud ... Corra. Você tem que fugir ... Você tem que viver.Nosso mundo se tornará parte dele ... um dia. Mas esse não vai ser o meu fim, Nem o seu. (...) O limite da criação. Cloud, me empreste sua força. Vamos desafiar o destino ... juntos.Esse é só um pequeno pedaço, que vale a pena conferir.

Es bietet einen tollen Einblick in die Charaktere nach dem Ende des Spiels und vor dem Film. Es ist auch wichtig um den Charakter Denzel besser zu verstehen, der im Film einen wichtigen Part einnimmt. Es ist schade, dass all das nicht im Film erklärt werden konnte aber zur selben Zeit ist es schön geschrieben und man fängt schnell an den Charakter zu mögen bzw. seinen Hintergrund zu verstehen und was er für ein paar andere Charaktere wie Tifa und Cloud bedeutet. Die Geschichten zu den anderen Charakteren sind super und es bietet einen Einblick in die postapokalyptische Welt von FF7.

I'm glad they've published this officially in English (the soft-cover version. The hard-cover is en Français). Reading this story hits different now that we're in the middle of a pandemic; this whole Geostigma thing and the fear and confusion the characters feel is eerily relatable.
